photo.title: Piazza San Marco, Venice (1926)

photo.description: Saint Mark's Square, Venice, Italy Piazza San Marco (often known in English as St Mark's Square), is the principal square of Venice, Italy. A remark often attributed to Napoleon (but perhaps more correctly to Alfred de Musset) calls the Piazza San Marco "The drawing room of Europe". It is one of the few great urban spaces in a Europe where human voices prevail over the sounds of motorized traffic, which is confined to Venice's waterways. It is the only urban space called a piazza in Venice; the others, regardless of size, are called campi. As the central landmark and gathering place for Venice, Piazza San Marco is extremely popular with tourists, photographers, and Venetian pigeons. The Piazza originated in the 9th century as a small area in front of the original St Mark's Basilica. It was enlarged to its present size and shape in 1177, when the Rio Batario, which had bounded it to the west, and a dock, which had isolated the Doge's Palace from the square, were filled in. The rearrangement was for the meeting of Pope Alexander III and the Emperor Frederick Barbarossa. The Piazza has always been seen as the centre of Venice. It was the location of all the important offices of the Venetian state, and has been the seat of the archbishopric since the 19th century. It was also the focus for many of Venice's festivals. It is a greatly popular place in Italy even today.
photo.tags: venice italy venezia italia saint mark square san marco piazza abigfave visualart sensational bej overtheexcellence rubyphotographer supershot theunforgettablepictures flickrdiamond otw anawesomeshot soe blueribbonwinner impressedbeauty vivid friends theperfectphotographer goldstaraward llovemypics travelerphotos colourartaward alfred de musset the drawing room europe napoleon venetian pigeons
photo.title: Saint Mark's Square, Venice, Italy

photo.description: Saint Mark's Basilica Facade, Venice, Italy Exterior The exterior of the basilica is divided in three registers: lower, upper, and domes. In the lower register of the façade five round-arched portals, enveloped by polychrome marble columns, open into the narthex through bronze-fashioned doors. Above the central door round three bas-relief cycles of Romanesque art. The external cycle frames a 19th century gilded mosaic (Last Judgment) that replaced a damaged one with the same subject (during the centuries many mosaics had to be replaced inside and outside the basilica, but subjects were never changed). Mosaics about St Mark relics’ stories are in the lunettes of the lateral portals; the first on the left is the only one in the façade preserved from the 13th century. In the upper register, from the top of ogee arches, statues of Theological and Cardinal Virtues, four Warrior Saints and St Mark watch over the city. Above the large central window of the façade, under St Mark, the Winged Lion (his symbol) holds the book quoting “Pax Tibi Marce Evangelista Meus” . In the lunettes of the lateral ogee arches are four gilded mosaics renewed in the 17th century. In the center of the balcony the Roman Horses face the square. The Greek Horses The Horses of Saint Mark were installed on the basilica in about 1254. They date to Classical Antiquity; by some accounts they once adorned the Arch of Trajan. The horses were long displayed at the Hippodrome of Constantinople, and in 1204 Doge Enrico Dandolo sent them back to Venice as part of the loot sacked from Constantinople in the Fourth Crusade. They were brought to Paris by Napoleon in 1797 but returned to Venice in 1815. After a long restoration, since the 1990s they have been kept in St Mark’s Museum (inside the basilica). The horses now on the facade of the cathedral are bronze replicas. The Four Tetrarchs As the Roman Empire began the process of disintegration, Emperor Diocletian imposed a new Imperial office structure: a four co-emperor ruling plan called The Tetrarchy. This porphyry statue represents the inter-dependence of the four rulers. It was taken from Constantinople, during the Fourth Crusade in 1204, and set into the south-west corner of the basilica (the above mentioned low tower) at the level of the Piazza San Marco. The missing foot of one of the figures was discovered in Istanbul in the 1960s, where it is still on display.
photo.tags: venice italy venezia italia saint mark san marco basilica facade square piazza anticando the greek horses four tetrarchs mosaic doge enrico dandolo hippodrome constantinople
photo.title: Saint Mark's Basilica Facade, Venice, Italy

photo.description: Saint Mark's Square looking west, Venice, Italy The Piazza is dominated by the Basilica, the Doge's Palace and the Basilica's campanile, which stands apart from it. The buildings around the Piazza are, counter-clockwise from the Grand Canal, the Doge's Palace, St Mark's Basilica, St Mark's Clocktower, the Procuratie Vecchie, the Napoleonic Wing of the Procuraties, the Procuratie Nuove, St Mark's Campanile and Loggetta and the Biblioteca Marciana. Most of the ground floor of the Procuraties is occupied by cafés, including the Caffè Florian and Gran Caffè Quadri. The Correr Museum and the Museum of Archaeology are located in some of the buildings of the Piazza. The Venetian Mint lies beyond the Biblioteca Marciana on the riva or bank of the Grand Canal. During the French occupation from 1797, Napoleon converted the Procuratie Nuove into his royal palace. He constructed a new wing to house his ballroom, and this caused the destruction of the Church of San Geminiano, built by Jacopo Sansovino. The Ala Napoleonica (Napoleonic Wing) was designed by Giuseppe Soli in 1810. The Napoleonic Wing was the last of the Piazza's buildings to be completed, excepting the campanile which has since been rebuilt, but to its original design. The Piazza has also served as inspiration for other public areas. Minoru Yamasaki used the site as a basis for the 5-acre (20,000 m2) Austin J. Tobin Plaza that was located at the World Trade Center in New York City until September 11th 2001.
photo.tags: venice italy venezia italia saint mark square san marco piazza otw
photo.title: Saint Mark's Square looking west, Venice, Italy

photo.description: Saint Mark's Basilica (Italian: Basilica di San Marco a Venezia), the cathedral of Venice, is the most famous of the city's churches and one of the best known examples of Byzantine architecture. It lies on St Mark's Square (in the San Marco sestiere or district) adjacent and connected to the Doge's Palace. Originally it was the "chapel" of the Venetian rulers, and not the city's cathedral. Since 1807 it has been the seat of the Patriarch of Venice, archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Venice. For its opulent design, gilded Byzantine mosaics, and its status as a symbol of Venetian wealth and power, from the 11th century on the building was known by the nickname Chiesa d'Oro (Church of gold). Source: Wikipedia
photo.title: St Mark's Basilica

photo.description: We got our coach to a point you don't usually see on TV / movies etc. We caught our boat with our holiday reps to go down the Canale delle Giudecca (Giudecca Canal) and then onto the Bacino di San Marco (Saint Mark's Basin) to where our boat docked, to let us off and into Venice itself. A dream come true, spending a day in Venice. It was very hot when we got there, something like 35 - 38 degrees centigrade. Piazza San Marco (St Mark's Square) is to the left from here. First views of the Doge's Palace (The Ducal Palace). As well as being closer to the Basilica di San Marco.
photo.tags: venice venezia veneto northernitaly italy canals cityofcanals canaledellegiudecca bacinodisanmarco boat piazzasanmarco stmarkssquare dogespalace theducalpalace stmarkscampanile campaniledisanmarco stmarksbasilica basilicadisanmarco worldheritagesite unesco unescoworldheritagesite
photo.title: Venice - Arrival by boat - Piazza San Marco

photo.description: We got our coach to a point you don't usually see on TV / movies etc. We caught our boat with our holiday reps to go down the Canale delle Giudecca (Giudecca Canal) and then onto the Bacino di San Marco (Saint Mark's Basin) to where our boat docked, to let us off and into Venice itself. A dream come true, spending a day in Venice. It was very hot when we got there, something like 35 - 38 degrees centigrade. On the left was the Basilica di Santa Maria della Salute, followed by the Punta della Dogana. The tower on the right is the St Mark's Campanile (Campanile di San Marco), the bell tower of the St Mark's Basilica (Basilica di San Marco).

photo.description: The inside of St. Mark's is filled with stunning mosaics. They're everywhere-- on the floor, ceiling, walls. The precision and patience that must have went into these is impressive. Photography inside the church was unfortunately prohibited, but I managed to snap a few of the mosaics near the entrance.

photo.description: Saint Mark's Basilica Facade, Venice, Italy Saint Mark's Basilica (Italian: Basilica di San Marco a Venezia), the cathedral of Venice, is the most famous of the city's churches and one of the best known examples of Byzantine architecture. It lies on St Mark's Square (in the San Marco sestiere or district) adjacent and connected to the Doge's Palace. Originally it was the "chapel" of the Venetian rulers, and not the city's cathedral. Since 1807 it has been the seat of the Patriarch of Venice, archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Venice. For its opulent design, gilded Byzantine mosaics, and its status as a symbol of Venetian wealth and power, from the 11th century on the building was known by the nickname Chiesa d'Oro (Church of gold).
photo.tags: venice italy venezia italia saint mark san marco basilica facade roman catholic otw
photo.title: Saint Mark's Basilica Facade, Venice, Italy

photo.description: Saint Mark's Campanile, Venice, Italy St Mark's Campanile is the bell tower of St Mark's Basilica in Venice, Italy, located in the square (piazza) of the same name. It is a recognizable symbol of the city. The tower is 98.6 meters tall, and stands alone in a corner of St Mark's Square, near the front of the basilica. It has a simple form, the bulk of which is a plain brick shaft, 12 meters on a side and 50 meters tall, above which is the arched belfry, housing five bells. The belfry is topped by a cube, alternate faces of which show walking lions and the female representation of Venice (la Giustizia: Justice). The tower is capped by a pyramidal spire, at the top of which sits a golden weathervane in the form of the archangel Gabriel. The campanile reached its present form in 1514. As it stands today, however, the tower is a reconstruction, completed in 1912 after the collapse of 1902.
photo.tags: venice italy venezia italia saint mark campanile san marco
photo.title: Saint Mark's Campanile, Venice, Italy

photo.description: Saint Mark's Basilica Facade, Venice, Italy The Piazza is dominated by the Basilica, the Doge's Palace and the Basilica's campanile, which stands apart from it. The buildings around the Piazza are, counter-clockwise from the Grand Canal, the Doge's Palace, St Mark's Basilica, St Mark's Clocktower, the Procuratie Vecchie, the Napoleonic Wing of the Procuraties, the Procuratie Nuove, St Mark's Campanile and Loggetta and the Biblioteca Marciana. Most of the ground floor of the Procuraties is occupied by cafés, including the Caffè Florian and Gran Caffè Quadri. The Correr Museum and the Museum of Archaeology are located in some of the buildings of the Piazza. The Venetian Mint lies beyond the Biblioteca Marciana on the riva or bank of the Grand Canal. During the French occupation from 1797, Napoleon converted the Procuratie Nuove into his royal palace. He constructed a new wing to house his ballroom, and this caused the destruction of the Church of San Geminiano, built by Jacopo Sansovino. The Ala Napoleonica (Napoleonic Wing) was designed by Giuseppe Soli in 1810. The Napoleonic Wing was the last of the Piazza's buildings to be completed, excepting the campanile which has since been rebuilt, but to its original design. The Piazza has also served as inspiration for other public areas. Minoru Yamasaki used the site as a basis for the 5-acre (20,000 m2) Austin J. Tobin Plaza that was located at the World Trade Center in New York City until September 11th 2001.

photo.title: Basilica di San Marco

photo.description: La Basilica di San Marco è il più grandioso dei monumenti di Venezia, quello che sopra ogni altro esprime la grandezza della storia della città lagunare. Fu costruita sui resti delle prime due chiese nel luogo dove la leggenda racconta che un angelo indicò a San Marco, in viaggio verso Roma, come luogo della sua sepoltura. La prima chiesa dedicata a San Marco, voluta da Giustiniano Partecipazio, l'undicesimo doge della Repubblica di Venezia, fu costruita accanto al Palazzo Ducale nell'anno 828 per ospitare le reliquie del santo trafugate, secondo la tradizione, ad Alessandria d'Egitto. Il primitivo tempio venne poco dopo rimpiazzato da un nuovo edificio collocato nel luogo attuale ed edificato nell'832 che però fu incendiato durante una rivolta nel 976 e quindi nuovamente ricostruito nel 978. La struttura della basilica attuale risale all’intervento avviato dal doge Domenico Contarini nel 1063 che seguì abbastanza fedelmente le dimensioni e l'impianto dell'edificio precedente. Nel 1094 avvenne la nuova consacrazione. La realizzazione continuata nell'arco di molti secoli della basilica, trasformata numerose volte e arricchita di tesori e manufatti preziosi in gran parte provenienti dall’oriente, si riflette nello stile architettonico che è insieme bizantino, romano e veneziano per l’apporto di artisti e artigiani di cultura e origini diversi. The Basilica of San Marco is the most magnificent monument in Venice, the one above all others that expresses the greatness of the history of Venice. It was built on the ruins of the first two churches in the place where the legend says that an angel pointed to a place of his burial at St. Mark's, traveling to Rome. The first church dedicated to San Marco, built by Justinian Partecipazio, the eleventh duke of the Republic of Venice, was built near the Doge's Palace in the year 828 to house the saint's relics came from Alexandria of Egypt, according to tradition. The original temple was soon replaced by a new building located in the existing site and built in 832 but it was burned down during a revolt in 976 and then rebuilt again in 978. The structure of the current basilica dates to the intervention launched by the doge Domenico Contarini in 1063 that followed quite closely the size and the planting of the previous building. In 1094 came the new consecration. The construction of the church continued over many centuries, turned several times and enriched with precious treasures and artifacts mostly from the East; this origin is reflected in the architectural style that is both Byzantine, Roman and Venetian for the contribution of artists and craftsmen of different origins and culture.
photo.tags: venezia venice italy basilicadisanmarco chiesa church sanmarco basilica romanico bizantino byzantine roman italia notte hdr venecia nocturna platinumheartaward bellitalia ohhh
photo.title: Venezia – La basilica di San Marco in Hdr

photo.description: detail of the beautiful church On the lower right are 2 of the 4 horses of St. Mark. These are actually replicas; the originals are inside in the museum. Their story is very interesting... from wiki: The Horses of Saint Mark were installed on the basilica in about 1254. They date to Classical Antiquity; by some accounts they once adorned the Arch of Trajan. The horses were long displayed at the Hippodrome of Constantinople, and in 1204 Doge Enrico Dandolo sent them back to Venice as part of the loot sacked from Constantinople in the Fourth Crusade. They were brought to Paris by Napoleon in 1797 but returned to Venice in 1815. After a long restoration, since the 1990s they have been kept in St Mark’s Museum (inside the basilica). The horses now on the facade of the cathedral are bronze replicas.

photo.title: Venice2007-2 454

photo.description: Day 130. We only had a short time in Venice - one night - and so didn't have time to get much off the beaten path. Thus, on the morning of our second day of vacation we headed for Saint Mark's. It is hard to take a photo of Piazza San Marco that has not been taken a thousand times already. Additionally, since we were there in the morning and the light was behind the church (and half the front facade was covered in scaffolding), I didn't really focus on the church itself. Instead, I tried to capture something that might represent how San Marco felt before it was overrun by cruise ship daytrippers - elegant cafes overlooking the central meeting place of a rich and aristocractic city. The sepia tone is maybe too much, I don't know. Three more in comments. Next up, Florence (although a few more Venice shots may make their way to Flickr over the next week or so). Taken May 9, 2012 in Venice, Veneto, Italy ¹⁄₃₂₀ sec at f/10, ISO100, no flash. Lens: EF-S10-22mm f/3.5-4.5 USM @ 10mm
photo.tags: 365photoproject architecture building cafe cathedral church mansion plaza tower venice veneto italy basilicadisanmarco
photo.title: The Venice of Old? [130/366]

photo.description: We got our coach to a point you don't usually see on TV / movies etc. We caught our boat with our holiday reps to go down the Canale delle Giudecca (Giudecca Canal) and then onto the Bacino di San Marco (Saint Mark's Basin) to where our boat docked, to let us off and into Venice itself. A dream come true, spending a day in Venice. It was very hot when we got there, something like 35 - 38 degrees centigrade. Piazza San Marco (St Mark's Square) is to the left from here. First views of the Doge's Palace (The Ducal Palace). As well as being closer to the Basilica di San Marco.
photo.tags: venice venezia veneto northernitaly italy canals cityofcanals canaledellegiudecca bacinodisanmarco boat piazzasanmarco stmarkssquare dogespalace theducalpalace stmarkscampanile campaniledisanmarco stmarksbasilica basilicadisanmarco worldheritagesite unesco unescoworldheritagesite
photo.title: Venice - Arrival by boat - Piazza San Marco
